title: Machining Theory
text:
Like any subtractive process, machining starts with a larger piece of material and removes what you don’t want. But the real shift isn’t in the process – it’s in how you learn to think.
When you design a part knowing you’ll machine it yourself, every feature gets evaluated differently:

Can I reach this surface with the tools I have? Internal corners need a radius at least as large as your endmill. A sharp inside corner on a drawing means a different setup or a different process.
How will I hold this part? Fixturing is half the battle. A beautiful design that can’t be clamped is a design that can’t be made.
What order do I cut features in? Removing material changes the part’s rigidity. Cut a thin wall too early and it will flex under the next operation.

This kind of thinking bleeds into everything else. When I design a PCB enclosure, I’m already thinking about how the mill will approach each pocket. When I lay out a 3D print, I’m thinking about support structures the same way I think about fixturing.
The machine teaches you to respect material, to plan operations in sequence, and to think three moves ahead. It’s the closest thing engineering has to chess.

title: Research
text:
I work at the Radiological Instruments Laboratory (RIL) at UC Santa Cruz, where my research focuses on improving PET imaging using cadmium zinc telluride (CZT) detectors.


Positron emission tomography is a medical imaging technique that detects pairs of gamma rays emitted from a radioactive tracer injected into the body. By detecting these gamma ray pairs, we can reconstruct 3D images showing metabolic processes – this is critical for cancer diagnosis, cardiac imaging, and neurological research.



Most PET scanners use scintillator crystals coupled to photomultiplier tubes. CZT is a semiconductor detector that converts gamma rays directly into electrical signals, offering:

Better energy resolution – sharper distinction between true events and scattered radiation
Room-temperature operation – no cryogenic cooling required
Compact form factor – enables novel detector geometries




Traditional CZT detectors orient the crystal face-on to incoming radiation. Our lab uses an edge-on geometry, where gamma rays enter through the thin edge of the crystal. This gives us:

A longer interaction path through the detector material
The ability to measure depth of interaction (DOI) from the charge carrier drift pattern
Better spatial resolution for the same crystal volume

I work on characterizing charge carrier transport through these edge-on crystals and developing modular detector units that can be tiled into larger imaging arrays.

title: Research
text:
Open-source instrumentation
One of my goals is to make experimental instrumentation more accessible. Projects in this area include:

CNC-automated detector scanning – Using open-source motion control to automate collimated beam experiments
Custom 3D-printed collimators – Low-cost alternatives to machined lead or tungsten collimators
Custom test fixtures – Machined and printed fixtures for repeatable detector positioning

See my projects page for details on the hardware I’ve built to support this work.

title: 3D Printed Featherboard
text: Featherboards hold stock firmly against the fence and table during routing and sawing operations. They prevent kickback and ensure consistent, safe cuts. Commercial featherboards work fine, but printing one in PLA lets you size it exactly for your setup and replace it when the fingers wear out.

title: 3D Printed Featherboard
text: Featherboards hold stock firmly against the fence and table during routing and sawing operations. They prevent kickback and ensure consistent, safe cuts. Commercial featherboards work fine, but printing one in PLA lets you size it exactly for your setup and replace it when the fingers wear out.

title: 3D Printed Featherboard
text:
Design



3D printed featherboard


The featherboard is printed in PLA, which provides just enough flex in the fingers to apply consistent pressure against the workpiece while guiding it along the fence. The angled fingers deflect as stock feeds through, then spring back – allowing forward movement while resisting kickback.
PLA works well here because it’s stiff enough to apply real pressure but has enough give to avoid marring the workpiece. When the fingers eventually fatigue and lose their spring, printing a replacement takes less than an hour.

title: 3D Printed Featherboard
text:
Result
A simple, effective shop tool that costs pennies to make and minutes to replace. It sees regular use at the router table and table saw.

title: Rong Fu 31 Milling Machine
text: I needed a milling machine rigid enough to do real work. My two previous mills were under 150 lbs each, and I was constantly fighting deflection and chatter. Lightweight benchtop mills are fine for drilling and light engraving, but the moment you try to take a serious cut in aluminum or steel, the lack of mass shows.

title: Rong Fu 31 Milling Machine
text: I needed a milling machine rigid enough to do real work. My two previous mills were under 150 lbs each, and I was constantly fighting deflection and chatter. Lightweight benchtop mills are fine for drilling and light engraving, but the moment you try to take a serious cut in aluminum or steel, the lack of mass shows.

title: Rong Fu 31 Milling Machine
text:
The Machine



RF31 3D model


I acquired this Rong Fu 31 from someone who could no longer store it. It had never been used – the original waxy shipping oil was still on every surface, and when I disassembled it for transport, the paint cracked at every joint, confirming I was the first person to do any maintenance on it.
The RF31 is a round-column mill/drill, weighing roughly 600 lbs. “Mill/drill” indicates its dual role: primarily a drill press, secondarily a lightweight milling machine. At 4x the mass of my previous machines, the improvement in rigidity was dramatic. Weight is king when it comes to precision – heavier machines absorb vibration and resist cutting forces far better.

title: Rong Fu 31 Milling Machine
text:
Upgrades

Digital Readout (DRO)



DRO installation


The problem: Manual milling without a DRO means counting handwheel graduations and keeping a running tally on paper. It’s slow, error-prone, and makes repeatable setups tedious.
The solution: I sourced a 3-axis DRO kit from AliExpress, specifying scale lengths to match the RF31’s travel distances from the manual. Most DRO kits come pre-packaged for specific machines with bolt-on brackets, but since there’s no RF31-specific kit available, I ordered bare scales and designed the mounting myself.

What I’d do differently: The glass scales are accurate but fragile – I’d add chip guards from the start next time rather than retrofitting them after getting swarf on a scale.

X-Axis Scale



X-axis DRO scale installation




Y-Axis Scale



Y-axis DRO scale installation

title: Rong Fu 31 Milling Machine
text:
Result
The DRO transformed the usability of this machine. Setups that used to take 15 minutes of dial-indicating now take seconds. Combined with the rigidity of the 600 lb frame, I can now hold tolerances that were impossible on my lighter machines.

title: 3D Printed Capsule Packer
text: Packing salt pills into capsules by hand is slow and inconsistent. Each capsule gets a slightly different fill, and the process is tedious enough that doing a large batch becomes impractical. I needed a simple tool to make capsule packing repeatable and fast.

title: 3D Printed Capsule Packer
text: Packing salt pills into capsules by hand is slow and inconsistent. Each capsule gets a slightly different fill, and the process is tedious enough that doing a large batch becomes impractical. I needed a simple tool to make capsule packing repeatable and fast.

title: 3D Printed Capsule Packer
text:
Design



Capsule packer assembly





Split view showing internal geometry


The packer is printed in PLA and designed to hold multiple capsules in alignment while a press mechanism ensures consistent fill. The geometry is sized to match standard capsule dimensions.
This is the third iteration of the design. The first version had tolerance issues – the capsules fit too loosely to stay aligned. The second revision tightened the pockets but made insertion difficult. V3 found the right balance between a snug fit and easy loading.

title: 3D Printed Capsule Packer
text:
Result
Three iterations to get it right, but the final version packs capsules consistently and quickly. A good example of how 3D printing lets you iterate through designs cheaply – each revision was a few hours of print time and a few cents of PLA.

title: ESP8266-12F Breakout Board
text:
The ESP8266-12F is a cheap, capable WiFi module useful for IoT projects and lab automation, but prototyping with the bare module is a pain. The castellated pads don’t fit a breadboard, and every new project means rewiring the same boot circuitry, voltage regulation, and serial interface from scratch.
I wanted a breakout board that makes the ESP8266-12F as easy to work with as dropping a dev board into a breadboard – but without paying for features I don’t need.

title: ESP8266-12F Breakout Board
text:
Design



V0.1 3D render





V0.1 schematic


The board breaks out the ESP8266-12F’s GPIO, I2C, SPI, UART, and ADC pins to breadboard-friendly headers with clear labels. Support circuitry handles 3.3V regulation, boot mode selection, and USB-serial for programming.
Designed in KiCad and fabricated by PCBWay.

The breakout board has become a go-to starting point for quick WiFi-enabled projects, cutting setup time from an hour of wiring to just plugging in a module.

title: Router Table V0
text:
Commercial router tables are either cheap and flimsy or expensive and locked into one configuration. I wanted something modular – a table I could reconfigure, add dust collection to, and adapt as my needs change – without spending more than the router itself costs.
Building it myself also meant I could size it for my shop and integrate it with my existing workflow.

title: Router Table V0
text:
Design and Build






Front view







Back view






Details






Dovetail detail







Front detail











Mounting detail







Dust collection port





The design prioritizes modularity – the fence, insert plate, and dust collection are all removable or reconfigurable. The dovetail joinery provides rigidity while keeping the table easy to disassemble for modifications.
The dust collection port routes directly from under the table surface, capturing chips at the source rather than relying on a separate hood over the workpiece.

title: Router Table V0
text:
Result
A functional router table that cost a fraction of a commercial equivalent while being fully customizable. The “V0” label reflects the fact that it’s a platform I keep improving – the modularity means upgrades are bolt-on rather than starting over.

title: Toolpost Grinder from a Trim Router
text:
Toolpost grinders are used on lathes to grind hardened materials and achieve surface finishes that cutting tools can’t match. Commercial toolpost grinders are expensive, and many are oversized for small hobby lathes.
I had an older Makita trim router with a plastic housing – too worn for precision routing, but still spinning at 25,000+ RPM. That’s close to what a small grinding spindle needs. The question was whether I could adapt it into a usable toolpost grinder.

title: Toolpost Grinder from a Trim Router
text:
Toolpost grinders are used on lathes to grind hardened materials and achieve surface finishes that cutting tools can’t match. Commercial toolpost grinders are expensive, and many are oversized for small hobby lathes.
I had an older Makita trim router with a plastic housing – too worn for precision routing, but still spinning at 25,000+ RPM. That’s close to what a small grinding spindle needs. The question was whether I could adapt it into a usable toolpost grinder.

title: Toolpost Grinder from a Trim Router
text:
Design



3D model of the toolpost grinder adapter


The adapter mounts the Makita trim router to the lathe’s toolpost, positioning the collet at center height. The trim router’s existing collet accepts standard 1/4” shank grinding points and mounted wheels.

title: Toolpost Grinder from a Trim Router
text:
What I’ve ground
This grinder has been genuinely useful for work that’s impossible with a cutting tool alone:

Tungsten carbide tooling – Grinding custom profiles on carbide blanks for specialized cuts
Hardened ballscrew shaft ends – Precision grinding shaft ends on hardened ballscrews to fit couplers

Both of these materials would destroy a conventional lathe tool. The trim router’s high RPM makes short work of them with the right grinding point.

title: Toolpost Grinder from a Trim Router
text:
Result
A functional toolpost grinder built from a retired trim router. It won’t replace a proper cylindrical grinder, but for occasional grinding of hard materials on the lathe, it’s been a worthwhile addition to the shop. The total cost was essentially just the adapter material and a set of grinding points.

title: About Me
text: I’m an electrical engineering student and researcher at UC Santa Cruz, where I work at the Radiological Instruments Laboratory on next-generation PET imaging detectors. I’m also a part-time employee at Slugworks, a makerspace in Baskin Engineering.

title: About Me
text:
How I work
I believe the best engineers operate at every level of abstraction. In the same week I might be simulating charge transport in a CZT crystal, designing a PCB to read out detector signals, and machining an aluminum fixture to hold the whole assembly. Being able to move between theory, electronics, and fabrication means I can go from idea to working prototype without waiting on anyone else.

title: About Me
text:
My shop
I maintain a small home shop with a Rong Fu 31 milling machine, a lathe, a router table, and a collection of 3D printers. Most of my projects start here – I prototype fixtures, tooling, and enclosures before bringing them into the lab.

title: About Me
text:
Philosophy
There is no substitute for experience. Mistakes accelerate learning by forcing you to be critical of your process. Small, incremental improvement is the goal.
